thread.title: Chris Young, the Royals $675,000 man, starts in Game 4 of ALCS
thread.title_full: Chris Young, the Royals $675,000 man, starts in Game 4 of ALCS - KCTV5

author: Neal Jones, News Producer/Editor
title: Chris Young, the Royals $675,000 man, starts in Game 4 of ALCS
text:
TORONTO (KCTV) - Other than his height (6'10"), nothing about Chris Young is intimidating. He acts a lot more like a mature father of three than a hot-shot major league pitcher. 
The 36-year-old righthander does not possess a blazing fastball. He doesn't glower and stomp around on the mound. He has not been an instigator of any of the Royals highly publicized confrontations/brawls. He is the lowest-paid pitcher on the Royals roster with a base salary of $675,000. (He is eligible for more than $5 million in bonuses based on days on the roster, innings pitched and games started).
What Young does do is mix up his pitches, change speeds and hits spots. At his best, he appears to be one step ahead of the hitters, using their strengths against them.
In short, the Princeton graduate out thinks the hitter. Perhaps that's why Royals manager Ned Yost will start Young against baseball's top offense Tuesday afternoon.
"He's got really good numbers against these guys," Yost told the media on Sunday. "His last two starts of the year were really, really good. We feel like he gives us a good chance to win."
Not everyone agrees. 
"The Royals should not start Chris Young in Game 4," read Monday's headline at the Royals Review website.
The writer's point is that a fly-ball pitcher like Young is vulnerable to fly ball hitters in a smaller ballpark like Toronto's Rogers Centre.
"When a Blue Jays hitter hits a fly ball, where does it land?" Shaun Newkirk writes. "For several Blue Jays players, that ball lands on the other side of the fence."
Young said he understands the challenge.
"You have to make good pitches, no  matter where you are," he said. "The challenge is to execute pitches, choose the right pitches, no matter where you are."
On Tuesday, Yost said execution will be key for Young.
"If you're executing your pitches where you want, you're going to nullify the power. You're going to keep them more off balance. If you're not, last night, we didn't execute. And today if we execute it's going to be a different story," he said.
As for pitching in the hitter-friendly Centre, Young says it's not about the ball park.
"I've had bad games in pitcher's parks and good games in hitter's parks. It's about the pitching, not the park," he said.
Young's only 2015 postseason appearance was in Game 1 of the Huston Astros series when he relieved Yordano Ventura. Young threw four innings, surrendering three hits and one run. The run came on a homer off a fastball.
That appearance followed two excellent starts to end the season, including his five innings of hitless baseball against the Cleveland Indians on Sept. 27.
So, like it or not "seamheads," Yost in going with his veteran on Tuesday.
Share your thoughts with us on our Facebook page. Click here.
